bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Paul Ehrlich, 1854-1915, physician and scientist, Berlin and Frankfurt, Germany. Founder of hematology, pioneer and major contributor to the fields of histochemistry and immunology. Famous for his development of chemotherapy (arsphenamine - 606) for syphilis. Nobel Laureate in physiology or medicine in 1908, jointly with Elie Metchnikoff for their studies in immunity.
Biographical Information: 1854 - Born March 14 in Strehlen, Silesia.
1872 - Graduated from St. Maria Magdalena Gymnasium in Breslau.
1878 - M.D. from the University of Leipzig, after studies at the Universities of Breslau, Strassburg and Freiburg.
1878-1888 - Assistant physician, later senior physician at the Charité Hospital in Berlin, director Professor von Frerichs.
1888/1889 - After contracting tuberculosis cured in Italy and Egypt.
1889 - Established a small private research laboratory in Berlin.
1890 - Appointment in the Robert Koch Institute for Infectious Diseases in Berlin.
1896 - Appointed director of the new State Institute for Serum Research and Serum Control in Steglitz, a suburb of Berlin.
1898 - This institute moved to Frankfurt and was expanded and renamed: The Institute for Experimental Therapy.
1906 - The Georg-Speyer wing for chemotherapeutical research was added with the private financial help of Mrs. Franzisca.
1908 - Nobel Prize in physiology and medicine.
1911 - Received the state rank of "Wirklicher Geheimer Rath" with the title of Excellency.
1914 - Named "Ordentlicher Professor" at the newly founded University of Frankfurt.
1915 - August 20, died in Bad Homburg and is buried in the Jewish Cemetery in Frankfurt.
Honorary Degrees: 1904 - University of Chicago, LL.D. 1907 - University of Oxford, D.C.L. 1911 - University of Athens, Dr. phil. h.c. 1911 - University of Breslau, Dr. med. h.c.

Awards: 1887 - Senckenberg Naturforschende Gesellschaft, Frankfurt a.M. Tiedemann Prize. 1903 - The Prussian Great-Golden Medal of Science. 1906 - Prize of Honor at the XVth International Congress of Medicine at Lisbon. 1908 - Nobel Prize. 1911 - Liebig Medal, Society of German Chemists. 1914 - Cameron Prize of Edinburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ehrlich papers is a special collection of the Rockefeller University comprising the contents of 3 unique collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Paul Ehrlich papers consists of three collections --
Paul Ehrlich papers (FA135) Paul Ehrlich and Martha Marquardt papers (Wellcome collection) (FA136) Pinkus family collection of Paul Ehrlich papers (FA072)
